application.name: enlarge
application.brief: Enlarge the pixel dimensions of an image
application.description: This program will enlarge a cube by a given scalar of the original or to specific dimensions. The user can specify to perform the enlargement by cubic convolution, nearest neighbor, or bi-linear interpolation.

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.description: Use this parameter to select the filename. All bands within the file will be enlarged unless a specific band is specified.

parameter.name: TO
parameter.description: This file will contain the results of the enlargement.

parameter.name: INTERP
parameter.description: This is the type of interpolation to be performed on the input.

option.description: Each output pixel will be set to the value calculated by a cubic convolution interpolation of the calculated input pixel.
Each output pixel will be set to the pixel nearest the calculated input pixel.
Each output pixel will be set to the value calculated by a bi-linear interpolation of the calculated input pixel.

parameter.name: MODE
parameter.brief: Scale up the image or enlarge to specific dimensions
parameter.description: Select between enlarging the image to a multiple of the original (by a scaling factor) or to specific dimensions (in terms of total number of pixels).

option.description: Enlarges the input image by a scaling factor. The scaling factor along the sample range and line range must then be specified in the SSCALE and LSCALE parameters, respectively.

option.brief: Enlarge to a total number of pixels
option.description: Enlarges the input image to a total number of pixels. The number of pixels in the output image along the sample range and line range must then be specified in the ONS and ONL parameters, respectively.

parameter.name: SSCALE
parameter.description: This determines new size of the cube in the sample direction only. The number of samples will be multiplied by this number.

parameter.name: LSCALE
parameter.description: This determines new size of the cube in the line direction only. The number of linees will be multiplied by this number.

parameter.name: ONS
parameter.description: The number of samples desired in the output cube. This value must be greater than or equal to the number of samples in the input image.

parameter.name: ONL
parameter.description: The number of lines desired in the output cube. This value must be greater than or equal to the number of lines in the input image.

example.brief: Enlarge the number of samples by a scaling factor of 2, while leaving the number of lines the same.
example.description: Here, the 1024 x 1024 image "peaks.cub" has had the application "reduce" applied to it in order to produce a 512 x 1024 image called "reducedPeaks.cub". In this example, the reduced image, reducedPeaks.cub, will be enlarged by a factor of 2 along the sample dimension in an attempt to restore it back to its original form.

terminalInterface.description: In order to double the number of sample pixels, the sample scale is set to 2.0, and the line scale remains at its default of 1.0. Since no mode or interpolation has been specified, the application will default to scale and cube convolution interpolation, respectively.

image.description: Screenshot of the GUI with parameters set to perform an enlargement of the samples by scaling.

This is the original image, before being reduced, that the enlarge application will attempt to replicate. It is important to realize that this image has been scaled down to fit in a web browser. At full size, the image would be 1024 x 1024 pixels.

image.brief: Input image for enlarge, output from reduce
image.description: This is the reduced image, containing half its original number of samples, that enlarge will attempt to restore. Though it has also been scaled down to fit in a web browser, at full size it would be 512 x 1024 pixels. For more information, see the documentation for the "reduce" application.

The enlarged image. Despite the fact that half the samples were lost as a result of the reduction, the two images (peaks.cub and restoredPeaks.cub) look nearly identical due to the cubic convolution interpolation that was applied. Again scaled down for web browsers, at full size, the image would be 1024 x 1024 pixels.

example.brief: Enlarge the number of samples to 768, and keep the number of lines at 1024
example.description: Here the mode has been set to enlarge to a total number of pixels along the sample and line dimensions, with all other parameters kept at their default settings.

terminalInterface.description: In order to enlarge to specific dimensions, the mode is set here to "total". Also, because total lines and samples do not have default values, the output number of lines must still be specified, even though they will be unchanged.

image.description: Screenshot of the GUI with parameters set to perform a sample enlargement to a total number of pixels.
This is the same input image, reducedPeaks.cub, that was enlarged in the last example.

The enlarged image. Though it has been scaled down so that it can be viewed in a web browser, the essential change can still be observed. The horizontal enlargement is noticable, and the output cube has 3/2 the number of samples as the input cube.
